The conception of impossibility to travel at the speed of light comes from looking at Einstein's theory of general relativity, E=mc^2.  The problem wouldn't be the weight increase, it would the energy required.  Think about it this way, the only thing scientists know can travel at the speed of light currently, is light itself.  Er, rather, photons of light.  Photons are actually little packets of light energy that do not have mass.  They do have momentum, however, which allows the photons to interact with mass.  But that's a different lesson.  Anyways, since it has a mass of 0, if we plug it into the equation, E=0c^2.   So factoring it out, using proper order of operations, would leave us with E=0.   Meaning 0 energy is needed to move that light photon.   Now to figure out how much energy we would need to move a person, we just plug in the mass of that person into the equation.  Now the average mass of a person is 62 kg. (about 137 pounds)  So then the energy needed equals to 62 times the speed of light, 1.079e+9 km/h (about 670459517 mph) times itself which equates to 1.164241e+18 (4.4951596e+17).   Now the equation looks something like this E= 62 *  (1.164241e+18).  This means the energy needed to move a 62 kg person move at the speed of light is 7.2182942e+19 joules of energy.  That's the same energy as 17252137200 metric tons of TNT.  That's more than double the total global arsenal of nuclear warheads.  That means, to travel just one single person, by themselves, without any equipment or vehicle, would take the combined effort of every government on two and a half Earths to happen.  This is not even including the apparatus needed to create such a situation.  The problem isn't that we would need infinite energy, and therefore be impossible, it's just that we would need so much energy that it just so implausible, it would be practically impossible to do so.

If they are moving at 0.9 c,  nine tenths of the speed of light,  then light beams sent forward from them will only travel at 0.1c relative to them.

That's so we, observing, can see them moving at 0.9c and light moving at c, as it must.

BUT, this is the 'tricky' thing: THEY measure the speed of their light as c, despite the fact that it is only moving ahead of them at 0.1c.

How come?  How to change the Speed = Distance/Time equation from the figures they've got to figures that give a result of 'c' ?

 Because they've got:  Distance:  0.1 light second ( a measure of distance) / Time: 1 second  and that should = 0.1c.

Obviously we have to change either Time or Distance or both.

what happens to a light beam shining backwards from them?

Here's my issue with Einstein's Relativity....(and forgive me if I'm missing something critical here)

Going back to the mirror on the train example...

I'm not sure I entirely understand why it's not conceivable that you wouldn't see your reflection in the mirror. In fact, if I understand how light behaves correctly, you wouldn't see anything in the mirror. It would be a pitch black circle in front of your face, because the mirror cannot produce any sort of image without light striking it, and if no light is striking it, then it's appearance would be the equivalent of looking at it in a dark room; no light = no image. 

Another thought to consider is that the medium in which the light is traveling through on your cosmic train must also be taken into consideration. Since an atmosphere affects light physically, is it not conceivable to hypothesize that the light being emitted inside the train would be - at least some small extent - "dragged along" with the moving atmosphere inside the train (thus surpassing it's natural speed of c)? The simplest analogy I can give is how passengers on a faster-than-sound traveling aircraft can still hear the noise inside the compartment, as well as engine noise. The sound waves are being affected by the medium in which they're traveling through. The atmosphere inside the compartment is also traveling supersonic, and  any sound waves emitted inside the compartment would, to an outside observer, be traveling FASTER than sound. However, if this were to be correct, then you theoretically WOULD still see your reflection as normal, because the light waves are being "carried" along with you via your atmosphere. 

Now if you were in a vacuum? That's a whole different story...

So Einstein imagined what would happen if he was travelling at the speed of light, and somehow looked at a light wave travelling next to him. If he was travelling at the same speed as the light wave, then that wave would appear to be standing still. This would violate Maxwell's Equations of electromagnetic radiation, so it led him to think that both the laws of physics and the speed of light must be the same, or invariant, in all reference frames.
